text:
- We wanna make sure that
Thomson Reuters is a place
where employees can grow their career.

- We have employees in
76 different countries,

so we needed to make sure that
we accommodated time zones
and local languages.

While the training that
we did with AWS Skills
Guild focused on cloud development,

we did incorporate AI training
into the program as well.

AWS Skills Guild was there
every step of the way with us.

- My team is actually located
across Canada, North America,
here in Switzerland, as well as in India.

And having a common training
that everyone has taken is key

for them to be able to
have a common language
and a common understanding.
With AWS Skills Guild,

we have trained over 3,100
employees at Thomson Reuters.

We are looking how we can
educate our users about creating
AI in a way that respects ethics
and it respects the rights of individuals.

The cloud training program
has both enabled my team

to understand how they can
leverage AWS capabilities
to create services within the platform.

With the help of AWS in our
data scientists that are newer

to the AI platform, we've
seen them being able

to move models that used to
take two weeks every month
to be run and maintained,
to now only needing two days at a time.

- The benefit we receive from
the AWS Skills Guild is it

helps us more readily make
cloud technologies in everyday
part of our working lives.
Sometimes you can find use cases

that are right there in
your day-to-day work.

What we've done within our
service management organization
is take incident data
and we're having the machine look at it

and tell us what patterns 
it can find from that.

I've seen AWS Skills Guild 
transform our culture,

not just the architects,
not just the developers,

people like that, but also the
analysts, the finance people.

I've got a level of knowledge
now that I didn't have before,
and then I could take that new knowledge

and come up with new, better
solutions for the business.
